for joining in today today's webinar is being recorded in the next few days we
will send you a follow-up email with the on demand links to the presentation deck and the webinar
recording and again I'd like to welcome everybody to our webinar getting started with AWS device Farm
our presenter today is Trent Peterson Trent is a project manager for AWS device Farm a mobile app testing
platform that helps developers automatically test their apps on hundreds of real devices in minutes and
catching issues before they're released into the wild he joined ads through the
acquisition of appac and an app testing company he co-founded prior to appac he
was at Intel designing system automation Solutions trusted to test products used by
millions of customers with an emphasis on Simplicity and user
experience today with us we also have Powell vorovich nikel deota and Andrew Hawker
they are our webinar moderators today and they will be engaging you with your questions and answers in the Q&A POD at
this time Trent welcome to the session and the floor is now yours
thanks Jerry and thanks all of you for joining us uh today to learn more about
device Farm um and how to test your mobile applications so before we get started I
want to walk through sort of why we built device Farm um so as you're likely well aware AS application developers uh
consumers have a very loud voice and can sort of make or break your mobile
application uh success within the markets so when an application doesn't work uh the first order of business is
to essentially let the developer know or let everybody else know by way of uh
reviews in the various markets and now why do they leave these
reviews and and so the the question can be answered by the fact that there are many many variables and variations um
that make it extremely complex as an application developer so essentially it's very frustrating for a consumer
because they expect an application to work on their phone their taet their television across all the myad devices that they might have and it's
frustrating from a developer standpoint because you have to deal with all of these devices and I'm not just talking about the fact that there are thousands
upon thousands of different screen resolutions um CPUs gpus and so on but
also the fact that we have carriers making modifications we have manufacturers making modifications we
have different uh stacks of Hardware we also have environmental factors so our
in users might be you know with with inconsistent connectivity but to them
they don't you know they don't know that that's what's causing their problems it's always the app is sort of the the
first stop for the blame and that affects of course uh your application's placement in the market and so it's it's
frustrating all around and so um so
that's why we built device farm and as a developer you're probably also used to collecting hardware and testing on
various devices and you well know that you know every shop that you go into pretty much has a cabinet or a desk or
even if it's a large company room upon rooms upon rooms of these devices um
available for testing by developers it's extremely expensive one to collect that
hardware and that's just this the the start you also have to wire all those
devices up keep them charged keep them up toate um maintain their stability and then also if you want to actually run
test Automation in a scalable fashion uh you have to to build that automation infrastructure and so developers were
telling us that this was a very large pain point for them um and this motivated us to build device
farm so what to expect in today's webinar uh we'll start with an overview
of what device Farm is and what its capabilities are in a brief history of the service uh then we'll go into a demo
uh so you don't just take my word for it um we actually will walk through scheduling a test and interpreting a
report um we'll talk a little bit about how to integrate device Farm into your development workflow and continuous
integration setups um including a demo um where we'll launch a test straight from Jenkins CI environment uh and
finally we will wrap up with Q&A uh where you can ask any questions um that you might have and of course you can ask
uh questions throughout the presentation um and the moderators will will help answer those and I will answer some at
the end so at its core a device Farm enables
you to test your mobile applications on real physical phones and tablets in the
AWS Cloud so these are not emulators these are not simulators these are real deal Hardware um the same exact Hardware
that you're carrying around your users are carrying around that you buy in the store um we support testing of on both
Android and iOS platforms the application types can be native hybrid
or web so whether you're building your application using xcode or Android
Studio or you're using a framework like zamarin or Unity or you're building a web application that loads in the mobile
browser you can test your applications uh with Device Farm now I mentioned that we have real
physical Hardware so we have hundreds of unique devices that you can choose from
so when I say unique device I refer to the make the model and the operating
system version that's running on it and when we do the demonstration I'll point this out as we're selecting devices now
behind each of those devices that you can choose from we actually have many instances of each so that those devices
are available to you for your tests when you need
them AWS device Farm is designed from the ground up with security in mind um so we have a couple um main main points
here one is that the on the hardware side the devices are actually physically isolated so you may be familiar with
with devices laying on tables or in racks um side by side our devices are
physically isolated from one another and this means a couple of things it means that the devices can't see each other so
there's no way for one phone to take a picture or a video or an audio recording of a device next to it um and then also
it means that the devices can't see each other from a wireless standpoint so Bluetooth traffic Wi-Fi traffic and so
on um on the software side the devices are dynamically Tethered to a host
machine so when you run your tests it runs on a host machine that has the device plugged into it over USB that
host machine that executes your code is brought up on the Fly runs your code and then is torn down it is not reused
between customers so you can be sure that your test code and your application are running on Fresh Hardware uh fresh
images and fresh Hardware um one more note on the
security side is that when your application is done being tested we uninstall the application we reset a
number of settings on the device we do a number of verification steps and if any of those fail and we cannot verify that
your IP was removed from the device we will quarantine the device and a technician will attend to that device if
we still cannot recover the device it will be destroyed um next up is flexibility so
our devices are exposed um for two primary uh use cases first you can
perform manual testing so with our remote access feature you can select a device get a window to that device's
screen right from within in your browser gesture touch and manipulate that screen
upload applications um and and perform manual tests uh reproduce customer
issues and so on and then at the end you'll get a video recording of that session along with the logs now as I
mentioned before because there are so many devices out there manual testing is simply not scalable so that's where
automation comes into play so if you've written automated tests for your application or even if you don't have automated tests written uh we can uh we
have a built-in feature that allows you to run automated tests without any scripting you were able to run those
automated tests that you've written or are automated tests for your application on many devices in parallel so you can
select one device you can select a 100 devices and then we will fan that test execution out across those devices and
then create an aggregate report that includes screenshots performance data logs and
video um and those reports are available through our console interface and we'll
walk through that in the demo those reports are also available through our apis which we'll get into in a little
bit um so about integration again we're going to go into a demo later in the
presentation where we'll launch uh a test straight from Jenkins we have official plugins for Jenkins and Android
studio um and Gradle and then through our sdks and CLI you can access our API
and so everything that I show you today within our console is important to note that everything you see is available
through our API um including the reports as I mentioned before and it's it's also
important to note that when you look at those reports and you see the layout and all of the results and videos and
screenshots that RPI actually allows very granular access to this so you can programmatically pull just the bits and
pieces that you want um through that
API so a little bit about pricing so unlimited testing starts at $250 per
month and this is based on test concurrency we call them device slots so
you can purchase let's say you purchase five android automated device slots you select 10 devices to run your test on it
will simply run five at a time so it' run five and then five you would get your report your full report back and
that would be build at $250 per slot so in that case um $1,250 per month and you
can run as much as you'd like through throughout the month schedule as many runs in in uh in parallel as you'd like
it's simply going to limit the number of devices that will execute tests to the number of slots you have for the relevant
type we also offer a pay as youo model so with no commitments no uh no upfront
charges you simply pay for the device minutes that you use so for instance if you run five devices your test take five
minutes you'd be charged for 25 device minutes at 17 cents per device minute
and after today's session I encourage you to give it a try um your first 250 minutes on AWS device Farm are
completely free availability um so we'll talk a
little bit about where to find a vice Farm uh so the service was launched in July of
2015 and it's in the US west region although it's important to note that
it's available globally and we have customers from around the world running tests on us
247 um and that again that the devices like I mentioned before are real they're
hosted in the US but they are not all us devices so for instance we recently deployed a number of uh India market
devices to our Fleet um and you can find device Farm in
the console under the mobile services section um simply go to the console
click on the icon and you'll be walked through a getting started guide um so you can be up and running with Device form
now before we get into the demo I'd like to take talk real quick about highle use cases that we've seen developers using
device Farm 4 so using things like our Android Studio Plugin or our CLI and
integrating with local development environments uh testing iterative changes during development this also
includes using remote access to verify functionality on uh manually exercising
a piece of functionality that perhaps tests don't exist yet for um so testing those iterative
changes we also see developers testing cumulative builds so through CI plugins
like Jenkins uh we see tests coming through perhaps on a nightly build U some are based on Commit um so as soon
as something gets pushed back into for instance Mainline a build is created and tests are executed
automatically and then we see uh developers that test and verify functionality just prior to release so
so maybe automation um isn't isn't as mature quite yet um for some developers
and so this gives them a chance to just run some basic smoke and uh validation tests just before release on a large
number of devices so they can be sure that there's no obvious gotas within their application um and they you know
they don't have to find out the hard way through their their in users um we also see developers using
the service to monitor their released applications so so for instance running tests periodically throughout the day
every single day um exercising basic functionality that hits their back end
and if something goes wrong um for instance if something goes wrong more than a couple Canary runs in a row uh
they can flag this as something to look and investigate um because it means that there might be an outage in um out in
the wild um and finally reproducing issues reported by analytics and in users so
you might get a report from a customer they might call in they might walk you through you know here's the device I'm running here's the operating system this
is what's happening uh we see developers using our remote access feature to grab a device that mirrors the device that
the customer is using and follow follow their steps and reproduce issues so that they can quickly doog them without
actually having to purchase and acquire the hardware um and use it locally um and with that I'm going to
jump over to a demo of device Barb okay so now we're looking at the project list
within device farm so I'm going to walk you through the the main Concepts um within the service and we'll go ahead

the first highlevel uh entity is a project and a project can be thought of as it's a generic workspace um that
allows you to organize your test results your device pools which is a concept that I'll get into in in a few minutes
um and your files and and sort of group those and so we see some developers use
projects for for instance a specific title so uh a title just for Android
they'll have a project the title for iOS they have another project uh some will use the same project for both IOS and

tests and and so on it's completely up to you
so go ahead and hop into a project um that I created for today's webinar and I

M8 go ahead and confirm and start the session and then as I mentioned before
what what will happen is that we go out to our physical devices in the fleet we

your session so we do a number of of validation steps just before it's it's released to you so you can be sure that
the device is healthy when you receive it now while we
wait we can actually go back over and we can see that our session that I requested is is still being prepared
while that's going let's go ahead and schedule an automated test run as well so I'll walk you through that so the

iOS as my application type and then I have the option to upload my application or select an application that I've
previously uploaded you can see I have an iOS application a IPA and an Android application APK file I can also go ahead
and upload a new build of my application which is what I will do and while that's
uploading a quick note about these files um that that you submit there's no instrumentation necessary on these these
binaries so you simply take your application binary upload it to us as is this could be the same binary that you
push out to beta testers that you used to test locally or even the application that you submit to the market and this
goes for both Android and iOS applications and on the iOS side um there's no need to Whit list our
devices or add our devices um or do anything of that sort you simply take your binary IPA upload it to us um and
we'll take care of the rest okay and so now once our application has been uploaded uh we show
some metadata that we've parsed out about it and the second step is to configure the test that you want to run
so I mentioned before that we have a number of uh different automation uh Frameworks that we support including a
couple built-in uh Frameworks that do not require any automated scripting on your behalf so we have an Explorer and a
fuzz test the Explorer will crawl your application in an intelligent manner so if it finds a menu it knows to open the
menu it'll click an item and it explores the application and it knows how to back its way back it knows how to avoid
getting stuck in a loop and it will take screenshots and video um of the entire session you can think of it as a naive
User it's not going to exercise the business logic of your app but it is pretty good at getting through the majority of the screen within your
application we also have a fuzz test that's built in again no scripting necessary that's going to hit the
application with random user input um in a really really rapid fashion and you have a few uh controls that you can
manipulate here um but it's just it's if you're familiar with chaos monkey or monkey testing um that's what we have
here now the if you've written tests for your application that exercise specific
business logic take screenshots and so on um we we support a number of Frameworks you can see those here a few
flavors of appium calibash instrumentation and UI automator uh for today's demo I'm I've
written instrumentation tests actually written in espresso um so instrumentation includes junit robotium
and espresso and again I can select a an application um uh test package that I
have previously upload loaded or just upload a new version of my
tests and similar to the application that we uploaded the test here do not
need to be instrumented or or modified in any way to run on device farm so you're not using a library that we've
written you're not writing code that locks you into device Farm these are the same tests you would run locally um one
thing to maybe note there that we see a lot of developers struggle with is that when you go from your local environment
maybe testing on emulator simulators and maybe a handful of devices when you scale that out to potentially hundreds
of different Hardware um makes and models uh we see we see people struggle
with with dealing with that sort of more hostile environment where device Hardware might be more finicky it might
not behave the way you're expect uh we see timeout issues and so on so it's really important that when you're writing your code even to run locally um
that it's written in a very defensive manner um so as to adapt to the various device profiles that are out
there okay so once we've uploaded our test
go ahead and go to the next step which is to select the devices so by default it selected a curated pool called top
devices and you can see that it's contains about five uh devices and we're
compatible with every single one um if you're application for instance said that it didn't work on a specific API
level and down then those if you had devices in the pool selected uh you would see a message saying that your
tests are not going to run on those devices because your application is not supported now in addition to that
curated pool we can create a new device pool and there are a couple ways to create a new
device pool one is to use a rule so for instance you could say I'm only
interested in Samsung devices and when we look at
Samsung devices down here we can see that they've all been selected ahead and clear that rule so
that's one way you can you can create a device pool and the the power there is that if you create it with rules those
rules are applied dynamically whenever you make a run schedule a run on this pool so as we're adding devices to the
fleet and making them available which we do on a weekly basis um your pool will
actually grow and adapt to the fleet as it exists at the time of your run being scheduled so if you're always interested
in testing on all tablets you can simply add a rule that says to test on tablets um and anytime we add a new tablet it
will automatically be included in your device pool now you can also explicitly select devices and
create pools that way so if you have analytics and you know that these 10 devices are the most popular devices
amongst your customers um you can create a pool for that and then you can modify
that pool um over time and and keep it up to date and then reuse that pool um
whenever you schedule a run for today's demo I'm going to go ahead and leave it on the curated pool
that it selected the top devices pool in the final step before we start
running our tests is to configure the devices state in environment so here you
can upload extra data and this allows you to upload a zip file cont containing
arbitrary data so if your tests or application consume media like screen uh
like images or video or music or anything like that you can do that here also if you have test configuration data
um or some sort of database you can upload that here as well um um and on Android we will unzip this to external
storage and on iOS we will unzip it um we place it inside of your application
sandbox in addition to that extra data you can install other applications so this allows you to install uh
dependencies of your application U maybe you have applications that your app can integrate with um and finally uh you can
actually test upgrade flows through this piece this piece of functionality so you upload the old version of your app here
you uploaded your new version in that step one um and then you actually test an upgrade flow uh through your
app um you can upload one or more applications and select the order in which they're going to be installed as
well next up is setting the radio States so you can dictate when uh what the
state of the radios will be when your application is launched for the first time uh so for instance you can disable
Wi-Fi to see how your application will respond without any internet connectivity on first launch
um and then to test things like Geo fencing and and location based Services
you can specify the devices location by latitude and longitude um so the devices
are of course in a in in AWS data centers but you can simulate that they
are anywhere in the world um by specifying the latitude and longitude and then finally you can test
localization functionality by specifying the language and dialect um that will be set on the device um to see see how your
app will display um when it's used in in um whichever Market your your app
happens to find itself and once we are ready to go and

developers using a strategy that involves testing on both emulators simulators and real devices and it comes
down to the types of tests if you're testing very very small unit tests in an incremental fashion while you're developing like you know does this
function still return true for instance then it probably doesn't make sense to run that on a real physical device
especially not lots of devices in parallel if however you're implementing a new feature or piece of functionality
or new flow especially if it concerns the you user interface an emulator or simulator is is an approximation
especially on the performance side so an emulator or a simulator is not going to have the same CPU stack it's not going to have the same Bluetooth stack there
are lots and lots of differences between the simulators and emulators and the actual real deal um and like I said
especially on the performance side so if then also carriers are making modifications manufacturers are making
modifications to the firmware so again your simulator emulator is not necessarily a one to1 mapping now
simulators and emulators great for testing those small incremental changes like I mentioned great for maybe a first
